author: @FOX10News
title: Storms knock power out around the Gulf Coast
text: Storms knock power out around the Gulf Coast MOBILE, Ala. ( [WALA](https://www.fox10tv.com/)) - A line of severe storms left many without power Friday morning. From Baldwin EMC - “We took a hard punch with the storms moving through this morning. Currently, we’re experiencing over 140 outages with more than 12,000 meters out. Transmission lines are down in the Bay Minette area. Our power supplier is working to get that restored. We have two other substations that took a hit and numerous scattered outages across the service territory due to trees on the lines and broken poles. Crews are out accessing the damage and restoring power. If you see downed powerlines do not approach and call 911 immediately. We ask for your patience as our crews work safely to restore power.” From Riviera Utilities - “Customers throughout our service area are experiencing interruptions in electric service due to high winds and fallen tree limbs as strong storms pass through Baldwin County. We are aware of these outages and crews have begun working to restore power in areas where it is safe for them to do so. We will update this post throughout the day as we have more information. If you are experiencing an interruption in service, please call our outage lines at 51-943-4999 for Foley or 251-625-4999 for Daphne. Our electric customers can simply text “OUT” to 251-943-4999 to report service interruptions as well. Stay safe!” Please [download the free FOX10 weather app](https://flowcode.com/p/iijgfWEf8?fc=0). This is a great way to get updates, radar, and alerts. Submit your [Weather Photos and videos here](https://www.fox10tv.com/page/send-us-weather-pictures/) Copyright 2024 WALA. All rights reserved.

author: Alex Portée
title: Teddi Mellencamp Says Brain, Lung Tumors Have 'Significantly Shrunk'
text:
Teddi Mellencamp has shared a hopeful update in her cancer journey after revealing earlier this year that melanoma had spread to her lungs and brain.
In a smile-filled video shared to Instagram April 23, the 43-year-old reality star shared that her brain tumors have "significantly shrunk" — a milestone she says is a positive sign that treatment is working.
"Exciting news, everyone," the television personality said in the video. "Honestly, the crying was already done, but I just finished with all of my scans, and my tumors have significantly shrunk, which doctors believe means that this all will work, and that I will be back to myself and feeling good."
In the caption of her post, Mellencamp added more details about her progress.
“One update I couldn’t wait to share! All tumors stage 4 (metastasized melanoma in my brain and lungs) shrunk or disappeared so I have 6ish more weeks of immunotherapy and doctors believe I will be healed if everything stays on course," she wrote. "Thank you to everyone who has sent their love, prayers, and positivity.”
Mellencamp, who has been transparent about her diagnosis and cancer treatment since 2022, shared that she has two more rounds of immunotherapy to go.
"I’m going to keep a positive outlook, because that’s the way my doctor just spoke to me," she said. "He’s like, 'You did this, you got this.'"
Mellencamp’s followers were quick to celebrate her post, which received more than 70,000 likes and 6,000 comments within three hours of being shared on the platform.
“I can’t stop crying tears of joy … I love you,” Tamra Judge, who also appears in the "Real Housewives" franchise, wrote.
"This is incredible news I’m so happy!!" Marysol Patton, of "Real Housewives of Miami" responded. "It was my therapeutic playlist !!!"
"What a wonderful report Teddi! This truly made my day I think of you all the time," another fan wrote.
Mellencamp was originally diagnosed with Stage 2 melanoma in October 2022, and she underwent several surgeries for the skin cancer.
Earlier this year, Mellencamp said doctors discovered several tumors in her brain and lung, which she confirmed were metastases of melanoma and would be treated with surgery and immunotherapy.

title: BOCI创业板ETF（159821）跌0.52%，半日成交额4.08万元|创业板_新浪财经_新浪网
text:

author: Laure-Anne Marxuach
title: Les Français à la traîne sur les heures travaillées: "Il faut surtout travailler mieux"
text:
L'OCDE a publié un rapport sur les heures travaillées des Français. Ils travaillent 1.389 heures dans l'année au bureau, contre 1.717 heures pour la moyenne de l'OCDE. Selon un récent rapport de l'OCDE, la France est toujours à la traîne concernant les heures travaillées en Europe . En 2023, un Français passait en moyenne 1.389 heures dans l'année au bureau, contre 1.717 heures pour la moyenne dans l'OCDE, ce qui représente 36 minutes de moins par jour.
L'Hexagone se situe juste au-dessus des Pays-Bas et de l' Allemagne , mais en-dessous de la Grèce (1.687), l'Italie (1.608), l'Espagne (1.563) ou encore la Belgique (1.437).
Alors qu' Emmanuel Macron ne cesse de chercher le plein-emploi, la priorité serait-elle que les Français travaillent plus? Les Grandes Gueules en ont débattu ce jeudi.
Meilleur salaire? "Bien sûr, il faut travailler plus", selon le consultant Antoine Diers. "Mais est-ce qu'on en a envie dans un pays où ton salaire est assez petit contrairement aux autres, et où on te prélève beaucoup sur ta fiche de paie et sur tes impôts?", demande-t-il.
Pour l'ancien conseiller politique, les charges pèsent trop lourd sur le pouvoir d'achat . "Avant de demander aux Français de travailler plus, il faudrait leur laisser plus le produit de leur labeur, arrêter de tout leur pomper", assure-t-il.
Zohra Bitan, cadre de la fonction publique, confirme. Elle ajoute que la question de l'emploi ne peut se régler sans une nouvelle vision du travail dans le pays. "Le système social n'encourage pas au travail, c'est le principal problème", répond-elle, en abordant les aides sociales, comme le RSA . "Il faut surtout travailler mieux", s'accordent-ils.
"Une année particulière" À l'inverse, Marie, cadre administrative en Corse et auditrice des Grandes Gueules , recontextualise les chiffres de l'OCDE.
"Il y a un cadre structuré, une réglementation qui fixe le nombre d'heures, c'est 1.607 heures par an, c'est-à-dire 35 heures par semaine", rappelle-t-elle. Concernant l'année précédente, elle était "un peu particulière" assure Marie, "avec une année de grâce avec la réforme des retraites ". Elle évoque aussi le travail des saisonniers, inactifs pendant une longue période, et le temps partiel.
"Beaucoup de personnes sont à temps partiel et ce n'est pas forcément un choix", continue-t-elle. Principalement des femmes , selon Zohra Bitan. "À partir de là, on ne peut pas dire que les Français ne travaillent pas assez", conclut Marie.
Sur le même sujet Peut-on regarder les JO 2024 au travail? "On utilise le téléphone, un peu dans un coin" Battus aux législatives, d'anciens députés galèrent pour retrouver un emploi "On va avoir plus de travail": après un début d'été morose, les saisonniers espèrent se rattraper Toutefois, "rappelons que même si on travaille peu, nous avons une productivité horaire parmi les plus importante au monde", précise Antoine Diers.

author: Ryan Mancini
title: Blue, harbor seal at New Bedford's Buttonwood Park Zoo, dies from bird flu - NewsBreak
text:
New Bedford
Blue, harbor seal at New Bedford’s Buttonwood Park Zoo, dies from bird flu
By Ryan Mancini,
19 minutes agoA 21-year-old harbor seal at Buttonwood Park Zoo in New Bedford, named Blue, died last week from highly pathogenic avian influenza, known as avian flu or bird flu. Diagnostic testing on Blue showed that he died from complications from the virus, which was likely contracted through contact with an infected wild bird, the zoo said in a statement released Wednesday.

author: Phuc Van – Translated by Thuy Doan
title: High tides to bring flooding to Southern region in coming days
text: On the afternoon of November 1, the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting released multiple alerts about a cold front moving toward Northern and Central Vietnam, which could bring heavy rainfall to the North Central Coast and Central Coastal regions due to adverse weather conditions. Additionally, strong winds may generate high waves in the Southern waters of the East Sea, coinciding with the high tide situation in Southern coastal areas. According to the center, sea levels in the Southeast region are currently rising due to high tides. Observations show that the highest water level at the Vung Tau Station reached 389 cm early on November 1. Forecasts indicate that from the evening of November 1 through November 2, sea levels in the Southeast region will continue to rise, particularly along the coast from Vung Tau to Ca Mau, where high tide levels could reach between 390 and 395 cm from midnight to 4 a.m. and again from noon to 4 p.m. Low-lying areas and regions outside the dike systems in this area are at risk of flooding due to the high tides. The National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting has issued an additional warning that from November 2 to 3, coastal sea levels in the Southeast region will continue to rise with the tides, possibly reaching 395-400 cm at the Vung Tau Station. These high tides may slow down flood drainage in rivers throughout the Southeast region, increasing the risk of flooding in low-lying coastal, riverside, and areas outside the dike systems, especially in the early morning and early afternoon hours. On November 1, the center also reported that a cold front had spread across much of the Northeast region and parts of North Central Vietnam. Northeasterly winds in the Gulf of Tonkin reached level 6, with gusts up to level 7. In the next 24 to 48 hours, the cold air is expected to continue spreading across remaining areas of the North Central Coast and parts of the Northwest and Central Coastal region. By tonight and into tomorrow morning (November 2), the Northern region will see cooler weather, with mountainous areas likely turning chilly. Average low temperatures are expected to be around 19-21 degrees Celsius, with mountainous areas at 16-19 degrees Celsius, and some high-altitude locations dropping below 15 degrees Celsius.

author: HispanTV
title: Exmilitar israelí se quita sombrero ante HAMAS: Respeto su resiliencia
text:
Un veterano sionista exalta a HAMAS por demostrar alta capacidad en la guerra contra Israel y asegura que no se ve ninguna señal de colapso en el grupo palestino.
El medio estadounidense New York Times en un artículo que cita como analista al ex general de división israelí, Glora Eiland, admite que pese a las tácticas devastadoras de Israel en la guerra en curso contra Gaza, está creciendo el escepticismo sobre la capacidad de Israel para desmantelar al Movimiento de Resistencia Islámica de Palestina (HAMAS).
En este sentido, el exmilitar israelí asegura que “desde un punto de vista profesional, tengo que respetar su resiliencia. No veo señales de un colapso de la capacidad militar de HAMAS o de su poder político para continuar liderando Gaza” .
El medio también hizo referencia a Michael Milshtein, un ex alto mando del cuerpo de espionaje israelí (Mossad) quien ha criticado las declaraciones de algunas autoridades del régimen, describiendo a HAMAS como en el punto de ruptura.
HAMAS declara que Israel nunca podrá eliminar a la Resistencia Milshtein había advertido que estas declaraciones podrían estar creando expectativas equivocadas sobre la duración de la guerra contra la Franja de Gaza, además de destacar que HAMAS no está colapsando, al contrario, todos los días lleva a cabo batallas difíciles contra el ejército israelí.
HAMAS ha destruido 720 vehículos militares de Israel en Gaza Observadores: HAMAS utiliza “armas más sofisticadas” contra Israel | HISPANTV La milicia élite palestina HAMAS está utilizando “armas más sofisticadas” en el combate con el ejército israelí en Gaza, avisan dos think tank estadounidenses.
Israel lanzó el 7 de octubre una campaña de ataques indiscriminadas a Gaza con el objetivo señalado de “eliminar a HAMAS” y liberar a decenas de retenidos israelíes, bajo custodia del grupo élite palestino. Más de 80 días después, ninguno de los objetivos se ha hecho realidad.
Ante esta coyuntura, la oposición y estrategas de Israel admiten que la ofensiva israelí no ha sido más que una derrota total y creen que la falta de estrategia y objetivos realistas en el campo de batalla resultará en elevar aún más la cifra de las bajas en las filas del ejército israelí.
Reuters: Túneles de HAMAS en Gaza; un laberinto mortal para Israel mmo/mrg
